user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of run_usock:
```c
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct MyData *md = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = md->urh;
  char buf[128];
  ssize_t got;

  make_blocking (md->sock);
  /* start by sending extra data MHD may have already read, if any */
  if (0 != md->extra_in_size)
  {
    send_all (md->sock,
              md->extra_in,
              md->extra_in_size);
    free (md->extra_in);
  }
  /* now echo in a loop */
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (md->sock,
                buf,
                sizeof (buf),
                0);
    if (0 >= got)
      break;
    send_all (md->sock,
              buf,
              (size_t) got);
  }
  free (md);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh,
                      MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function run_usock:
struct MyData
{
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh;
  char *extra_in;
  size_t extra_in_size;
  MHD_socket sock;
}
...
struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment modifies the function parameter variable 'cls'. The code only reads 'cls' (struct MyData *md = cls;) and then operates on the object pointed to by that pointer via the local variable md (calls like make_blocking(md->sock), send_all(..., md->extra_in, ...), free(md->extra_in), free(md)). Rule 17.8 allows modification of the object referred to by a pointer parameter but forbids modifying the pointer parameter itself; there are no assignments to or mutations of the parameter variable 'cls' in run_usock. Therefore no fragments need further investigation under Rule 17.8.
